H0.text: Charting where birds fly is not an example of observation and measurement.

H1.text: Attracting birds with birdseed is not an example of observation and measurement.

H2.text: Counting the number of birds that fly by is not an example of observation and measurement.

H3.text: Illustrating the different birds that fly by is not an example of observation and measurement.

A4.text: The systematic, careful collection of measurements or counts of relevant quantities is often the critical difference between pseudo-sciences, such as alchemy, and science, such as chemistry or biology.

A5.text: Counts of things may represent a sample of desired quantities, with an uncertainty that depends upon the sampling method used and the number of samples taken.

A6.text: The rate of bird migration over the Alps (up to a height of 150 m) was found to be highly comparable between fixed-beam radar measurements and visual bird counts, highlighting the potential use of this technique as an objective way of quantifying bird migration.

A7.text: Visual bird counts at stopover sites can be very useful for estimating how long unmarked birds remain in a pre- or post-nuptial migratory stopover area.

A8.text: BirdCast – Live bird migration and forecast maps in the United States

A9.text: Hawkcount.org – Count data and site profiles for over 300 North American Hawkwatch sites

A10.text: Birders may take part in censuses of bird populations and migratory patterns which are sometimes specific to individual species.

A11.text: These birdwatchers may also count all birds in a given area, as in the Christmas Bird Count, or follow carefully designed study protocols.
